content: The Dawn of the Cyborg Journalist As A.I. increasingly infiltrates journalism, the reporting and consumption of news will change forever Thomas McMullan Blocked Unblock Follow Following Apr 17 Illustration by Luka Lavrenci C ould A.I. personalization go too far, reinforcing our existing interests and opinions rather than the traditional journalistic role of introducing the reader to important new information selected by experienced editors? If you happened to be watching the Chinese state broadcaster Xinhua in March, you might have noticed something strange. During the country’s largest political event of the year, TV anchor Xin Xiaomeng presented a piece on delegates arriving by train. But there was something unreal about her — literally. Xin Xiaomeng is a digital composite, one created with the help of machine learning to mimic the facial expressions and speech-patterns of a real-life news anchor. Xin Xiaomeng is part of the growing ranks of artificial newsreaders on Xinhua, all of them flawlessly delivering whatever is fed to them, without tiring, without slipping up, and without protesting. For a country that already keeps its journalists on a tight leash, this is an unnerving development, especially when you consider that Xin Xiaomeng is modeled on an actual Xinhua journalist named Qu Meng. Automated journalism looks like one more way for the government in Beijing to control of the distribution of information. Seen against this loss of journalists, a robot reporter looks like an attractive tool. For now, Xin Xiaomeng’s words are written by a human, and the system’s intelligence is limited to converting text to speech. To really understand how A.I. is changing the news, you need to look at how it is working behind the scenes. Automated reporting In January this year, the Guardian published an article on Australian political donations with the byline “ReporterMate.” ReporterMate is, in the words of the Guardian , an “experimental automated news reporting system” that can analyze a given data set and spit out a simple piece of writing in response. The system’s designer, Nick Evershed , argues that “news organizations have fewer staff but still need to cover a large amount of news,” and that an A.I. reporter could help with rote stories, freeing time for humans to work on meaningful investigations. Newspaper newsroom employees dropped by 45% in the United States from 2008 to 2017, according to a survey by Pew Research . The start of this year saw more than 2,000 job losses across a host of digital outlets, including BuzzFeed and Vice . Seen against this loss of journalists, a robot reporter looks like an attractive tool, capable of pulling data together into routine reports while the remaining humans deploy their skills on more complex stories. It isn’t just that a machine is doing something a human reporter would have normally done, but that it is capable of doing more than a human could do — at least measured by raw quantity. But the appeal of A.I. isn’t only in filling the gaps left by job losses. Using A.I., “we have been able to produce stories that we probably wouldn’t have done otherwise,” says Jeremy Gilbert, director of strategic initiatives at the Washington Post . For the past few years, the Post has also been experimenting with automation, centered on a piece of in-house technology called Heliograf. During the 2016 Rio Olympics, Heliograf generated hundreds of short reports on the games. During the 2016 U.S. elections, it was used to help cover close to 500 races . Instead of picking a few bellwether political races to cover, Heliograf allows a news organization to report, to some degree, on all of them. When Associated Press (AP) similarly started using A.I. to generate financial stories in 2014, the number of its corporate earnings reports increased tenfold, so much so that it actually affected trading volumes in financial markets. Using a different system, AP will soon begin generating previews of all 1,250 NHL regular-season games . Crucially, it isn’t just that a machine is doing something a human reporter would have normally done, but that it is capable of doing more than a human could do — at least measured by raw quantity. Algorithmic curation Things get complicated when you consider how to serve that machine-generated sprawl to an audience. Instead of flooding its front page with hundreds of articles about political races, the Washington Post geolocated users during the 2018 midterms as a way of offering them relevant pieces. If you were in Pennsylvania, for example, the website would suggest A.I.-generated reports on your local races. “The idea is that instead of writing one to many, you’re writing one-to-one across many, and that’s critical,” Gilbert says. “Ideally, from my perspective, we want to get to a place where, with information you are willing to share, we can give you stories you might be interested in that other people wouldn’t be.” Reg Chua, chief operating officer of editorial at Reuters, shares a similar vision. “We’ve built news around the notion that we write something and we publish it to as many people as possible,” he tells me. “That’s very much a model of broadcasting to everyone at the same time and needing a story that appeals to as many people as possible.” Instead, Chua asks, what if a news organization’s coverage was so all-encompassing that this model could be upended? “If I want to write a story about U.K. schools and how they’re doing, what a reader really wants to know is how their child’s school is doing,” Chua says. “Could I write that piece using a combination of A.I. and automation, so that you essentially have a one-to-one story?” Sports scores, political results, house prices, school performance reports: These might be pretty harmless areas for an A.I. to cook up hundreds of micro-reports and dish them out to the “right” readers. But could personalization go too far, reinforcing our existing interests and opinions rather than the traditional journalistic role of introducing the reader to important new information selected by experienced editors? “There is a danger that, even within a single publication, tweaking what people see in reflection of their own personal interests and preferences creates an echo chamber effect,” warns Josh Cowls, a research associate in data ethics at the Alan Turing Institute, the U.K.’s national institute for data science and artificial intelligence. There’s a comparison to be made to YouTube, Cowls says, which has faced strong criticism for pushing people to increasingly extreme content through its recommendation engine. “You may reinforce what people think. Your news preferences could come to code what you see, which means you may end up going down an ever-narrowing corridor of choice.” Origami journalism In addition to complicating which articles are shown to whom, A.I. systems could also play an increasing role in deciding what information is shown within individual stories. The Washington Post ’s Gilbert says one area of interest for him has been looking at how machine intelligence could be used to change the architecture of articles themselves, depending on what was known about the reader. He gives the example of a story about the ongoing civil dispute in Venezuela. “For some people, all we need to say is ‘what did Maduro do?’ or ‘did the aid trucks make it across the border?’” Gilbert says. “That new information is important to them because they’ve been following the story. On the other hand, if they’ve not paid any attention to the story, then we need to tell them who’s involved, why it’s an issue, how long it’s been going on.” Think about an online article less like a static print news story and more like a piece of origami, with sections folded and unfolded depending on who happens to be reading. In this case, the A.I. becomes an editor, reshaping paragraphs to fit different pairs of eyes. “It absolutely changes the relationship between a reporter, an editor, and news and their audience,” Gilbert says. But does it change that relationship for the better? At what point does this A.I. personalization cross the line from being helpful to the reader’s time to being unwieldy, even obfuscating? “It certainly raises ethical questions, because the input data going into the system relates as much to the audience as the news itself,” Cowls says. “You get into legal questions about personal information. Ethically, there are questions of identity and preference.” Changing the content of articles depending on who is reading them “really challenges traditional newsroom ethics.” For an algorithm to determine which version of a story to show a reader, it would need to make a call on how much that person already knows about a topic. That could be based on reading history, but there would be a legal question about how this data gathering squares with laws such as the General Data Protection Regulation in Europe, which has strict rules on how companies use personal information. More generally, how far should a newspaper go in painting a picture of a person’s knowledge about the world? It might be one thing to proactively ask readers about the content areas that interest them, with the intent of steering similar stories toward them, something many media brands — including Medium  — already do. It might be something else entirely for a brand to use machine learning to passively absorb a reader’s interests, possibly without the reader even knowing. Similar concerns about the manipulation of information and civil discourse have led social media companies into difficult territory. Lucas Graves, a senior research fellow at the Reuters Institute for the Study of Journalism, agrees that changing the content of articles depending on who is reading them “really challenges traditional newsroom ethics.” Editors today use their professional judgment to decide what information to include where, so it would be radical for newsrooms to hand that authority to computers. Machine investigation Arguably the most meaningful potential impact of machine learning is not on the audience-facing side of journalism, but rather in digging out stories for human journalists to work on. Reuters has developed a number of A.I. newsgathering systems, including News Tracer, which is designed to unearth breaking stories by scanning Twitter with algorithms that search for clusters of tweets discussing the same event. It gauges the trustworthiness of the information based on a number of factors, including whether a Twitter account is verified, who its followers are, whether there is attached media, and the structure of the tweet itself. Another Reuters project, Lynx Insights, searches big data sets like stocks or sports scores, flagging trends and anomalies and even penning a few sentences before handing it over to a human journalist. Instead of a robot reporter, Lynx Insights is more like a journalist’s personal data scientist. It’s a similar approach to the one that BuzzFeed took when it trained an algorithm to sift through flight data to recognize spy planes, or when ProPublica used machine learning to study thousands of press releases to analyze what Congress talks about . “Probably the most useful thing A.I. can do is analyze data,” says Chua of Reuters. “And you can see how in the future you could start marrying these things together. You analyze the data through an A.I. system automatically, and then that turns it into a story automatically.” It seems inevitable that these automated processes will eventually become connected. A system like Reuters’ Lynx Insights could automatically find a potential story, feed this information to a version of the Guardian ’s ReporterMate to write, and then pass that story to an artificial newsreader like Xin Xiaomeng to read on live TV — the whole process completed without a single human in the loop. “The more we mechanize this stuff, the more we might start to think, ‘Hang on, what is the added value?’” Cowls says. “And what is the added value of editorial at all if all we’re trying to do is collect facts and spread them out? It’s a dangerous path to go on… [Y]ou may end up in a situation where the integrity of not only a publication at large but also the story is devalued by this process.” This dystopian level of news automation is, hopefully, unlikely. Both Chua and Gilbert admit we are in the early stages of exploring how A.I. fits with journalism, and the technology is not yet sophisticated enough to stray beyond the most contained of data sets. “Reporters will still be needed for a while yet,” writes the Guardian ’s Evershed. But even if we’re not talking about artificial anchors reading automated news, we need to tread carefully. Given that the information these systems produce is wrapped in the implied credibility of a news story format, it is vital to keep tabs on what goes into machine-made reporting, whether that’s the background data, the words themselves, or who gets to see those words. The readers, after all, are only human.
title_html: The Dawn of the Cyborg Journalist
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Sign inGet started

  • INDUSTRY
  • SCIENCE & MEDICINE
  • ABOUT

The Dawn of the Cyborg Journalist

As A.I. increasingly infiltrates journalism, the reporting and consumption of news will change forever

Thomas McMullan
Apr 17

Could A.I. personalization go too far, reinforcing our existing interests and opinions rather than the traditional journalistic role of introducing the reader to important new information selected by experienced editors?

If you happened to be watching the Chinese state broadcaster Xinhua in March, you might have noticed something strange.

During the country’s largest political event of the year, TV anchor Xin Xiaomeng presented a piece on delegates arriving by train. But there was something unreal about her — literally. Xin Xiaomeng is a digital composite, one created with the help of machine learning to mimic the facial expressions and speech-patterns of a real-life news anchor.

Xin Xiaomeng is part of the growing ranks of artificial newsreaders on Xinhua, all of them flawlessly delivering whatever is fed to them, without tiring, without slipping up, and without protesting. For a country that already keeps its journalists on a tight leash, this is an unnerving development, especially when you consider that Xin Xiaomeng is modeled on an actual Xinhua journalist named Qu Meng. Automated journalism looks like one more way for the government in Beijing to control of the distribution of information.

Seen against this loss of journalists, a robot reporter looks like an attractive tool.

For now, Xin Xiaomeng’s words are written by a human, and the system’s intelligence is limited to converting text to speech. To really understand how A.I. is changing the news, you need to look at how it is working behind the scenes.

Automated reporting

In January this year, the Guardian published an article on Australian political donations with the byline “ReporterMate.” ReporterMate is, in the words of the Guardian, an “experimental automated news reporting system” that can analyze a given data set and spit out a simple piece of writing in response. The system’s designer, Nick Evershed, argues that “news organizations have fewer staff but still need to cover a large amount of news,” and that an A.I. reporter could help with rote stories, freeing time for humans to work on meaningful investigations.

Newspaper newsroom employees dropped by 45% in the United States from 2008 to 2017, according to a survey by Pew Research. The start of this year saw more than 2,000 job losses across a host of digital outlets, including BuzzFeed and Vice. Seen against this loss of journalists, a robot reporter looks like an attractive tool, capable of pulling data together into routine reports while the remaining humans deploy their skills on more complex stories.

It isn’t just that a machine is doing something a human reporter would have normally done, but that it is capable of doing more than a human could do — at least measured by raw quantity.

But the appeal of A.I. isn’t only in filling the gaps left by job losses. Using A.I., “we have been able to produce stories that we probably wouldn’t have done otherwise,” says Jeremy Gilbert, director of strategic initiatives at the Washington Post. For the past few years, the Post has also been experimenting with automation, centered on a piece of in-house technology called Heliograf. During the 2016 Rio Olympics, Heliograf generated hundreds of short reports on the games. During the 2016 U.S. elections, it was used to help cover close to 500 races.

Instead of picking a few bellwether political races to cover, Heliograf allows a news organization to report, to some degree, on all of them. When Associated Press (AP) similarly started using A.I. to generate financial stories in 2014, the number of its corporate earnings reports increased tenfold, so much so that it actually affected trading volumes in financial markets. Using a different system, AP will soon begin generating previews of all 1,250 NHL regular-season games. Crucially, it isn’t just that a machine is doing something a human reporter would have normally done, but that it is capable of doing more than a human could do — at least measured by raw quantity.

Algorithmic curation

Things get complicated when you consider how to serve that machine-generated sprawl to an audience. Instead of flooding its front page with hundreds of articles about political races, the Washington Post geolocated users during the 2018 midterms as a way of offering them relevant pieces. If you were in Pennsylvania, for example, the website would suggest A.I.-generated reports on your local races.

“The idea is that instead of writing one to many, you’re writing one-to-one across many, and that’s critical,” Gilbert says. “Ideally, from my perspective, we want to get to a place where, with information you are willing to share, we can give you stories you might be interested in that other people wouldn’t be.”

Reg Chua, chief operating officer of editorial at Reuters, shares a similar vision. “We’ve built news around the notion that we write something and we publish it to as many people as possible,” he tells me. “That’s very much a model of broadcasting to everyone at the same time and needing a story that appeals to as many people as possible.”

Instead, Chua asks, what if a news organization’s coverage was so all-encompassing that this model could be upended? “If I want to write a story about U.K. schools and how they’re doing, what a reader really wants to know is how their child’s school is doing,” Chua says. “Could I write that piece using a combination of A.I. and automation, so that you essentially have a one-to-one story?”

Sports scores, political results, house prices, school performance reports: These might be pretty harmless areas for an A.I. to cook up hundreds of micro-reports and dish them out to the “right” readers. But could personalization go too far, reinforcing our existing interests and opinions rather than the traditional journalistic role of introducing the reader to important new information selected by experienced editors?

“There is a danger that, even within a single publication, tweaking what people see in reflection of their own personal interests and preferences creates an echo chamber effect,” warns Josh Cowls, a research associate in data ethics at the Alan Turing Institute, the U.K.’s national institute for data science and artificial intelligence. There’s a comparison to be made to YouTube, Cowls says, which has faced strong criticism for pushing people to increasingly extreme content through its recommendation engine. “You may reinforce what people think. Your news preferences could come to code what you see, which means you may end up going down an ever-narrowing corridor of choice.”

Origami journalism

In addition to complicating which articles are shown to whom, A.I. systems could also play an increasing role in deciding what information is shown within individual stories. The Washington Post’s Gilbert says one area of interest for him has been looking at how machine intelligence could be used to change the architecture of articles themselves, depending on what was known about the reader.

He gives the example of a story about the ongoing civil dispute in Venezuela. “For some people, all we need to say is ‘what did Maduro do?’ or ‘did the aid trucks make it across the border?’” Gilbert says. “That new information is important to them because they’ve been following the story. On the other hand, if they’ve not paid any attention to the story, then we need to tell them who’s involved, why it’s an issue, how long it’s been going on.”

Think about an online article less like a static print news story and more like a piece of origami, with sections folded and unfolded depending on who happens to be reading. In this case, the A.I. becomes an editor, reshaping paragraphs to fit different pairs of eyes. “It absolutely changes the relationship between a reporter, an editor, and news and their audience,” Gilbert says.

But does it change that relationship for the better? At what point does this A.I. personalization cross the line from being helpful to the reader’s time to being unwieldy, even obfuscating? “It certainly raises ethical questions, because the input data going into the system relates as much to the audience as the news itself,” Cowls says. “You get into legal questions about personal information. Ethically, there are questions of identity and preference.”

Changing the content of articles depending on who is reading them “really challenges traditional newsroom ethics.”

For an algorithm to determine which version of a story to show a reader, it would need to make a call on how much that person already knows about a topic. That could be based on reading history, but there would be a legal question about how this data gathering squares with laws such as the General Data Protection Regulation in Europe, which has strict rules on how companies use personal information. More generally, how far should a newspaper go in painting a picture of a person’s knowledge about the world? It might be one thing to proactively ask readers about the content areas that interest them, with the intent of steering similar stories toward them, something many media brands — including Medium — already do. It might be something else entirely for a brand to use machine learning to passively absorb a reader’s interests, possibly without the reader even knowing. Similar concerns about the manipulation of information and civil discourse have led social media companies into difficult territory.

Lucas Graves, a senior research fellow at the Reuters Institute for the Study of Journalism, agrees that changing the content of articles depending on who is reading them “really challenges traditional newsroom ethics.” Editors today use their professional judgment to decide what information to include where, so it would be radical for newsrooms to hand that authority to computers.

Machine investigation

Arguably the most meaningful potential impact of machine learning is not on the audience-facing side of journalism, but rather in digging out stories for human journalists to work on.

Reuters has developed a number of A.I. newsgathering systems, including News Tracer, which is designed to unearth breaking stories by scanning Twitter with algorithms that search for clusters of tweets discussing the same event. It gauges the trustworthiness of the information based on a number of factors, including whether a Twitter account is verified, who its followers are, whether there is attached media, and the structure of the tweet itself.

Another Reuters project, Lynx Insights, searches big data sets like stocks or sports scores, flagging trends and anomalies and even penning a few sentences before handing it over to a human journalist. Instead of a robot reporter, Lynx Insights is more like a journalist’s personal data scientist. It’s a similar approach to the one that BuzzFeed took when it trained an algorithm to sift through flight data to recognize spy planes, or when ProPublica used machine learning to study thousands of press releases to analyze what Congress talks about.

“Probably the most useful thing A.I. can do is analyze data,” says Chua of Reuters. “And you can see how in the future you could start marrying these things together. You analyze the data through an A.I. system automatically, and then that turns it into a story automatically.”

It seems inevitable that these automated processes will eventually become connected. A system like Reuters’ Lynx Insights could automatically find a potential story, feed this information to a version of the Guardian’s ReporterMate to write, and then pass that story to an artificial newsreader like Xin Xiaomeng to read on live TV — the whole process completed without a single human in the loop.

“The more we mechanize this stuff, the more we might start to think, ‘Hang on, what is the added value?’” Cowls says. “And what is the added value of editorial at all if all we’re trying to do is collect facts and spread them out? It’s a dangerous path to go on… [Y]ou may end up in a situation where the integrity of not only a publication at large but also the story is devalued by this process.”

This dystopian level of news automation is, hopefully, unlikely. Both Chua and Gilbert admit we are in the early stages of exploring how A.I. fits with journalism, and the technology is not yet sophisticated enough to stray beyond the most contained of data sets. “Reporters will still be needed for a while yet,” writes the Guardian’s Evershed.

But even if we’re not talking about artificial anchors reading automated news, we need to tread carefully. Given that the information these systems produce is wrapped in the implied credibility of a news story format, it is vital to keep tabs on what goes into machine-made reporting, whether that’s the background data, the words themselves, or who gets to see those words. The readers, after all, are only human.

title: The Dawn of the Cyborg Journalist
content_html:
The Dawn of the Cyborg Journalist

As A.I. increasingly infiltrates journalism, the reporting and consumption of news will change forever

Thomas McMullan
Apr 17

Machine investigation

Arguably the most meaningful potential impact of machine learning is not on the audience-facing side of journalism, but rather in digging out stories for human journalists to work on.

Reuters has developed a number of A.I. newsgathering systems, including News Tracer, which is designed to unearth breaking stories by scanning Twitter with algorithms that search for clusters of tweets discussing the same event. It gauges the trustworthiness of the information based on a number of factors, including whether a Twitter account is verified, who its followers are, whether there is attached media, and the structure of the tweet itself.

Another Reuters project, Lynx Insights, searches big data sets like stocks or sports scores, flagging trends and anomalies and even penning a few sentences before handing it over to a human journalist. Instead of a robot reporter, Lynx Insights is more like a journalist’s personal data scientist. It’s a similar approach to the one that BuzzFeed took when it trained an algorithm to sift through flight data to recognize spy planes, or when ProPublica used machine learning to study thousands of press releases to analyze what Congress talks about.

“Probably the most useful thing A.I. can do is analyze data,” says Chua of Reuters. “And you can see how in the future you could start marrying these things together. You analyze the data through an A.I. system automatically, and then that turns it into a story automatically.”

It seems inevitable that these automated processes will eventually become connected. A system like Reuters’ Lynx Insights could automatically find a potential story, feed this information to a version of the Guardian’s ReporterMate to write, and then pass that story to an artificial newsreader like Xin Xiaomeng to read on live TV — the whole process completed without a single human in the loop.

“The more we mechanize this stuff, the more we might start to think, ‘Hang on, what is the added value?’” Cowls says. “And what is the added value of editorial at all if all we’re trying to do is collect facts and spread them out? It’s a dangerous path to go on… [Y]ou may end up in a situation where the integrity of not only a publication at large but also the story is devalued by this process.”

This dystopian level of news automation is, hopefully, unlikely. Both Chua and Gilbert admit we are in the early stages of exploring how A.I. fits with journalism, and the technology is not yet sophisticated enough to stray beyond the most contained of data sets. “Reporters will still be needed for a while yet,” writes the Guardian’s Evershed.

But even if we’re not talking about artificial anchors reading automated news, we need to tread carefully. Given that the information these systems produce is wrapped in the implied credibility of a news story format, it is vital to keep tabs on what goes into machine-made reporting, whether that’s the background data, the words themselves, or who gets to see those words. The readers, after all, are only human.
